                    });                 });             }          } })();  There would be no dramatic comeback or postgame delirium at Yankee Stadium, in contrast to the previous two days. The Yankees, for the third time this series, had an opportunity to win with a hit. But the Oakland Athletics held on for a 5-4 win Sunday.The loss ended the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 seven-game winning streak, but the mood in the postgame clubhouse remained celebrative. The team finished the homestand 7-2 and seemed to have righted its play without once dipping below the Baltimore Orioles in the American League East.Baltimore, trailing by one game, also lost Sunday, to the Boston Red Sox.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99d love for everybody behind us to lose every day, but we don\xe2\x80\x99t need that to happen,\xe2\x80\x9d Derek Jeter said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe control what happens. We went out and played well this homestand.\xe2\x80\x9dSo the clubhouse speaker system blared with tunes from \xe2\x80\x9cStar Wars.\xe2\x80\x9d Pitchers David Phelps, Justin Thomas, Cody Eppley, Adam Warren and infielder Melky Mesa were made to dress in the movie-themed costumes for the ensuing trip, a form of rookie initiation. Even Kenji Nimura, the interpreter for Hiroki Kuroda, was in on the act, dressed as Yoda. Photo       Alex Rodriguez after being called out on strikes. The Yankees ended their homestand 7-2.  Credit             Barton Silverman/The New York Times           The veterans in the locker room looked on in amusement, but the fact was not lost that the Yankees had an opportunity to put extra breathing room between them and their pursuers but still could not do so. The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 daily mimicry has made them a frustrating team to shake. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s crazy that you go 7-1 and you don\xe2\x80\x99t gain any ground on the team behind you,\xe2\x80\x9d Nick Swisher said, referring to the Orioles. \xe2\x80\x9cIt shows you they\xe2\x80\x99re here to stay and they are having a magical season.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Sunday\xe2\x80\x99s game again came down to the final at-bat, and for the seventh consecutive time these teams have met, the game was decided by one run. The competition could get no closer between two clubs, and these two could ultimately meet each other in October.It would have been hard to top Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s 14-inning, pulsating affair, which featured a four-run Yankees comeback in the bottom of the 13th inning and was eventually won, 10-9.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The hangover from Saturday \xe2\x80\x94 the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 longest game since May 2002 \xe2\x80\x94 contributed to some flat and lackadaisical play. The teams combined for five errors, two by Yankees shortstop Eduardo Nunez, including one that put the go-ahead run aboard in the sixth. Photo       The Athletics\xe2\x80\x99 Josh Donaldson scored the winning run on a hit in the sixth inning, as Russell Martin covered the plate.  Credit             Barton Silverman/The New York Times           There was also understandable fatigue, and both teams\xe2\x80\x99 pitching staffs were left thin. Yankees long relievers Derek Lowe and Freddy Garcia were inactive after making lengthy appearances, and only Rafael Soriano, David Robertson, Adam Warren (a starter) and Phelps were held out of Saturday\xe2\x80\x99s game, as far as relievers go. That left it up to starter Hiroki Kuroda to give the Yankees some innings.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Under that pressure, Kuroda was clearly not pitching with his maximum command or confidence. He started off shaky, needing 24 pitches to get out of the first, then he fell behind by 3-0 after a two-run homer by Cliff Pennington in the third. His slider did not have its usual effectiveness, and his overall command was uncharacteristically off. He walked more than two batters for the first time since June 19.\xe2\x80\x9cI was trying to hit those corners, and I got behind in the count,\xe2\x80\x9d Kuroda said through Nimura.He also threw two wild pitches and allowed seven hits and five runs (four earned) before being relieved with two outs in the sixth. On a day when the Yankees really needed him to last, Kuroda failed to finish six innings for the first time since July 6.\xe2\x80\x9cBecause of the game yesterday, I wanted to go longer in the game,\xe2\x80\x9d Kuroda said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut unfortunately I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9dThe Yankees rallied with a four-run fourth inning, tying the score with a two-run homer by Swisher, followed by a run-scoring double by Raul Ibanez and a fielder\xe2\x80\x99s choice R.B.I. by Nunez. That gave the Yankees a 4-3 lead. Photo       Hiroki Kuroda, who allowed five runs in five and two-thirds innings, took the loss.  Credit             Barton Silverman/The New York Times           Naturally, after the seesawing the teams have done in their last six matchups, it did not take long before the Athletics tied it (in the fifth) and then took a 5-4 lead in the sixth, after an error by Nunez at shortstop put Josh Donaldson into scoring position. He came around to score on a single by Pennington.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s bad,\xe2\x80\x9d Nunez said. \xe2\x80\x9cI have to keep playing defense well. I have to finish the play. I have to do it. I have to come in with confidence.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  In the ninth, Alex Rodriguez lifted a ball deep to right field that looked as if it might have a chance to go out. The fans rose as A\xe2\x80\x99s right fielder Josh Reddick drifted back to the wall. Could it be another last-gasp comeback?Reddick made a small leap, perhaps for dramatic effect, but the ball landed safely in his glove. The magic had run out.INSIDE PITCHThe Yankees held a moment of silence before the game for John Cashman, the father of General Manager Brian Cashman. John Cashman died Saturday from pancreatic cancer. He was 72. ... Derek Jeter increased his hitting streak to 17 games with a single in the third inning. [('Orioles Split Doubleheader and Lose Ground - The New York ...', '     Supported by    Baseball |                            Playoff Push                                                             With Doubleheader Split, The Orioles Lose Ground  By THE NEW YORK TIMESSEPT. 24, 2012    Continue reading the main story Share This Page  Continue reading the main story                if (             window.magnum             && window.magnum.getFlags().indexOf(\'headlineBalancer\') > 0             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.shouldRun()         ) {             window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize();         }        As the baseball season moves into its final stretch, the story lines are becoming clearer. Three National League teams \xe2\x80\x94 San Francisco, Cincinnati and Washington \xe2\x80\x94 have clinched spots in the postseason, and Atlanta seems assured of joining them as a wild-card team. That leaves St. Louis fighting off Milwaukee and the Dodgers for the second wild-card slot. The Brewers\xe2\x80\x99 loss to the Nationals on Monday afternoon made the Cardinals\xe2\x80\x99 task a little easier.The American League is more complicated, and compelling. No one has clinched a postseason spot, although TEXAS started the day with a comfortable four-game lead in the American League West. Baltimore and the Yankees were clinging to each other in the A.L. East division race. Detroit and the White Sox were doing the same in the A.L. Central, and the Angels were still hoping to move up into one of the top two wild-card spots, perhaps at the expense of Oakland, which was beginning a three-game series in Texas.The battle is on. (NYT)ORIOLES AND BLUE JAYS SPLIT J. P. Arencibia broke open a tight game with a seventh-inning grand slam, and Toronto beat host Baltimore, 9-5, to earn a doubleheader split and drop the Orioles to a game and a half out of first place in the A.L. East.In the opener, Adam Jones went 4 for 4 with a homer and two runs batted in to lead Baltimore to a 4-1 win. In the second game, Edwin Encarnacion hit his 41st home run for the Blue Jays, who snapped a seven-game skid. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      The Orioles lost a half-game in the standings to the Yankees, who won at Minnesota. (AP)WHITE SOX 5, INDIANS 4 Adam Dunn homered twice, including a three-run shot in the eighth inning, and the White Sox maintained their one-game lead over the Tigers in the A.L. Central. Photo       Adam Jones had four hits to lead the Orioles to victory in Game 1 of a doubleheader.  Credit             Patrick Smith/Reuters           Dunn, who now has 41 homers, also went deep in the sixth as Chicago snapped a five-game losing streak. (AP)TIGERS 6, ROYALS 2 Justin Verlander (16-8) breezed through eight innings and Prince Fielder hit a solo homer, helping host Detroit steady itself. The Tigers had been swept in a doubleheader on Sunday by Minnesota. (AP)  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  RANGERS 5, ATHLETICS 4 Adrian Beltre singled home the winning run in the bottom of the ninth inning as Texas rallied past Oakland to stretch its A.L. West lead over the Athletics to five games with nine to play. ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('Orioles beat Blue Jays 4-1 in 1st game of DH', "View photosBaltimore Orioles' Adam Jones watches his two-run home run in the fourth inning of the first baseball game of a doubleheader against the Toronto Blue Jays in Baltimore, Monday, Sept. 24, 2012. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky)MoreBALTIMORE (AP) -- Adam Jones has waited his entire career to be in a pennant race, and he's making the most of it.Jones went 4 for 4 with a homer and two RBIs, and the Baltimore Orioles moved within a half-game of the AL East lead with a 4-1 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays on Monday in the opener of a doubleheader.Ryan Flaherty hit a solo shot for the Orioles, who matched the division-leading New York Yankees in the win column (88). New York was scheduled to play at Minnesota on Monday night.The victory also solidified Baltimore's grasp on the top AL wild-card slot over Oakland.Jones' four hits tied a career high. He has hit safely in 18 of 22 games in September, with six home runs and 13 RBIs.''Adam relishes competition,'' Orioles manager Buck Showalter said. ''He's obviously had a heck of a year. He's turning into quite a player.''Asked if Jones deserves consideration for AL MVP, Showalter replied, ''This team, we haven't really thought about that type of stuff yet. That will be fodder when our work's done here.''Now in his seventh season, Jones has already set a career high with 32 homers, and his two runs scored put him over 100 for the first time. After enjoying his fifth multi-RBI game this month, the All-Star center fielder needs to drive in three more runs to eclipse his previous high of 83, set last year.Orioles rookie Steve Johnson (4-0) allowed three hits over five shutout innings to lower his ERA to 1.62. Half his big league wins have come against Toronto.Although the Jays got two runners on base in three of the first four innings, Johnson worked out of trouble on each occasion.''When you do that, you have to make a pitch in there, just bear down, throw a few pitches, make sure they don't make good contact on it,'' he said.Jim Johnson, the fifth Baltimore pitcher, worked the ninth for his 48th save in 51 opportunities.It was the seventh straight loss for the Blue Jays, matching a season high. Toronto has been outscored 46-17 during the skid, which began during a three-trip to Yankee Stadium and continued in Tampa Bay.''We can't run from what's taking place, and yet we have to continue to battle,'' Blue Jays manager John Farrell said.Henderson Alvarez (9-14) gave up four runs, eight hits and three walks in 5 2-3 innings. He's 2-7 in his last 10 starts.Speaking through an interpreter, Alvarez addressed the two homers he yielded by saying, ''Pitch to Jones was high changeup. He's a good hitter and he did what he was supposed to do with that pitch. The other kid, the second baseman, (I) felt like it was a good pitch and he did a good job with it.''In the fourth, Chris Davis walked and Jones followed with a drive to left to put Baltimore up 2-0. Flaherty connected in the fifth, and Jones singled in the sixth and came home on a double-play grounder.Toronto scored in the eighth on an RBI double by Rajai Davis. With runners on second and third and two outs, Darren O'Day came in to strike out Kelly Johnson.NOTES: Toronto purchased the contracts of RHPs Shawn Hill and Bobby Korecky and transferred LHP J.A. Happ (foot) to the 60-day DL. ... Orioles LHP Randy Wolf is experiencing discomfort in his left elbow and will undergo an MRI on Tuesday. ... Seventeen of Jones' HRs have given the Orioles the lead. Baltimore is 23-8 when he homers. ... Toronto has lost six straight in Baltimore during a single season for the first time since 1980, and the Orioles won the season series for the first time since 2004. ", 'www.yahoo.com'), ('Orioles miss big chance in 9th, lose to Boston - USA TODAY', 'The Red Sox\'s Andrew Bailey collected his sixth save of the season. (Photo: Steven Senne, AP)Story HighlightsDespite loss, Orioles don\'t lose ground on YankeesThe Red Sox avoid a sweep and stopped its four-game losing streakThe Orioles dropped to 27-9 in one-run gamesCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREBOSTON (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles ended a successful road trip with a wasted opportunity to climb into a tie for the AL East lead.When Ryan Flaherty struck out with the bases loaded in the ninth inning Sunday, the Red Sox had a 2-1 win and the Orioles headed home after going 6-3 on the journey to Oakland, Seattle and Boston.BOX SCORE: Red Sox 2, Orioles 1"We needed this one. Obviously, going down to this last stretch every game is looked at as a must win," Adam Jones said. "We had a good road trip. We really, really wanted this one to finish off the road trip, but it happens."The Orioles remained one game behind the New York Yankees and lead the Oakland Athletics by one game for the top wild-card spot in the league. The Athletics beat the Yankees 5-4.The Red Sox snapped a four-game losing streak -- and ended the Orioles six-game winning streak -- but are trying to finish out of the division cellar with their first losing record since 1997."Coming to Boston, take two out of three, I don\'t care what kind of team we\'re playing or how we\'re playing," Baltimore\'s Mark Reynolds said. "It\'s always big and we keep winning series, and we\'ll see where we\'re at here in a week or two."The Orioles almost completed a three-game sweep after Cody Ross doubled in the go-ahead run in the eighth. They loaded the bases with one out against Andrew Bailey on a single by Reynolds, a ground-rule double by pinch-hitter Jim Thome and an intentional walk to Chris Davis. But Boston\'s closer got Manny Machado to ground into a forceout at home, then struck out Ryan Flaherty to nail down his sixth save in eight opportunities."I like to work fast, but sometimes I work too quickly and get ahead of myself," Bailey said. "Today I was able to slow myself down and make the pitches when I needed to."The decisive run came in when Dustin Pedroia led off the eighth with a double against Luis Ayala (5-5) and Ross followed with his tiebreaking hit.In the first inning, Ross reached over the short right-field wall near Pesky\'s Pole in the corner to take a home run away from Jones."I didn\'t really know where I was, actually. I thought that the ball was in front of the pole after I had caught it," Ross said. "I ran in and somebody was like \'You just robbed a home run.\' I was like \'I did? All right. Cool.\' "Junichi Tazawa (1-1) pitched a perfect eighth before the Orioles rally fell short.Baltimore dropped to 27-9 in one-run games.Boston starter Felix Doubront struck out 11 in seven innings, including three each against Robert Andino and Reynolds. Andino returned after being hit in the helmet with a pitch on Friday night.With the pitcher\'s mound in the sun and home plate in a shadow until later in the game, hitters had a tough time picking up pitches, especially from a lefty."It was tough. Guys were trying sunglasses, no sunglasses, light lens, dark lens," Reynolds said. "Both teams were playing in the same conditions. It\'s probably why the score was 2-1."Baltimore manager Buck Showalter thought plate umpire Al Porter\'s vision might not have been perfect either. He said Matt Wieters, who led off the ninth by grounding out, should have walked had Porter not called a pitch a strike."Wieters really walked and we would have scored a run," Showalter said, "but, unfortunately, we weren\'t the only ones having trouble seeing the baseball, it looks like."After Ross drove in the go-ahead run, Brian Matusz retired Mauro Gomez on a fly ball before highly touted prospect Dylan Bundy made his major league debut with one out and retired both batters he faced on fly balls. Chosen fourth in last year\'s draft, the 19-year-old right-hander was 9-3 with a 2.08 ERA in the minors this year before being called up from Class AA on Wednesday."I was nervous at first," Bundy said. "I was hoping to get an inning, but getting those first two outs, that inspires me a little bit and, hopefully, the next time I won\'t be as nervous."Doubront allowed one run on four hits with two walks in his second consecutive solid start after losing his previous five decisions.The Red Sox scored the first run in the fourth when Ross led off with a single and took second on a walk to James Loney. With one out, Danny Valencia grounded to shortstop J.J. Hardy, who threw to second for the first out, but Andino\'s relay into the dirt eluded Reynolds at first base. Ross scored from second, sliding ahead of the attempted tag by Wieters.Doubront held the Orioles hitless through four innings and gave up hits to the first three batters in the fifth. Lew Ford singled, took third on a double by Davis and scored on a single by Machado.Notes: After the game, the Red Sox held a postgame ceremony for Johnny Pesky, who died Aug. 13 at the age of 92 after a baseball career of more than 60 years. He played, managed and served as a broadcaster for the team. ... The Red Sox recalled OF Che-Hsuan Lin from Triple-A Pawtucket... John Lackey, on the disabled list all year following Tommy John elbow surgery, pitched two innings in a Red Sox intrasquad game in Fort Myers, Fla. He threw 26 pitches with three strikeouts, no hits and no walks. ... The Orioles return home to open a four-game series Monday with a doubleheader against the Toronto Blue Jays. Steve Johnson (3-0) pitches for Baltimore against Henderson Alvarez (9-13) in the opener and Wei-Yin Chen (12-9) goes for the Orioles against Rickey Romero (8-14) in the nightcap. ... The Red Sox have a day off before opening their final home series of the season with the first of two games against the Tampa Bay Rays. Clay Buchholz (11-6) is scheduled to pitch for Boston against David Price (18-5).CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORECopyright 2012 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. ', 'www.usatoday.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 Jim Thome, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 42-year-old designated hitter, has slugged 611 home runs. The creases around his eyes date him, like rings around a tree trunk, and he has earned the right, after 22 seasons, to arrive at the ballpark later than most teammates.On Monday, before the Orioles played a doubleheader against Toronto, Thome saw the team\xe2\x80\x99s prized pitching prospect, the 19-year-old Dylan Bundy, walk into the clubhouse.According to Manager Buck Showalter, Thome then made it clear that he should never beat Bundy to the ballpark again. And on Tuesday, Showalter said with a smile, Bundy arrived at Camden Yards at 11 a.m.\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got the right amount, I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to say awe, but respect for everything,\xe2\x80\x9d Showalter said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut not to the point where he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t think he can do it.\xe2\x80\x9d Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Bundy, a 6-foot-1 right-hander who was the fourth pick of the 2011 draft, made his Camden Yards debut on Tuesday night, pitching a scoreless ninth in a 4-0 loss to the Blue Jays. He allowed one hit and one walk and threw mostly fastballs, with several touching 95 miles per hour.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The loss kept the Orioles one and a half games behind the Yankees in the American League East race. The Yankees fell to the Minnesota Twins, 5-4.Earlier this season, all indications were that his path to the major leagues would not be rushed. But Bundy dazzled in the minors, the Orioles pushed into the thick of a playoff race, and a marathon game in Seattle left their bullpen in need of reinforcements.On Sept. 18, the Orioles played an 18-inning game against the Mariners that lasted 5 hours 43 minutes. Bundy, who was 9-3 with a 2.08 earned run average in 23 starts in three minor league cities, was called up from the team\xe2\x80\x99s instructional camp in Sarasota, Fla., the next morning.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  His arrival was the latest plot twist on the Orioles team filled with castoffs and journeymen that is improbably surging toward its first postseason berth since 1997. Photo       Dylan Bundy has joined the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 staff as the team continues its unlikely run to the postseason.  Credit             Anthony Bolante/Reuters           \xe2\x80\x9cObviously, he\xe2\x80\x99s advanced for a 19-year-old,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jim Johnson, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 closer. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s pretty funny to say he\xe2\x80\x99s 19 years old. So far, he\xe2\x80\x99s what they\xe2\x80\x99ve billed him as.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Bundy made his debut against the Red Sox on Sunday. He entered in the eighth inning and retired both batters he faced in the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 2-1 loss. Bundy was a starter in the minor leagues, and his role as a reliever during the rest of the regular season, and perhaps beyond, is unclear.\xe2\x80\x9cOur front office and our manager are not afraid to do stuff,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ron Johnson, who manages the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Class AAA Norfolk affiliate and has been called up to Baltimore to serve as a coach. \xe2\x80\x9cI mean, the kid pitched at Fenway Park the other night. Our goal is to win, and I think whoever can help win will get an opportunity.\xe2\x80\x9d [{"headline":"Sports","summary":"Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, delivered to your inbox every week.","product-code":"SP","product-title":"Sports","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/sports?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=SP&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Race\\/Related Newsletter","summary":"Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with New York Times journalists.","product-code":"RR","product-title":"Race Related","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/race-related?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=RR&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Your Money","summary":"Every week, get tips on retirement, paying for college, credit cards and the right way to invest.","product-code":"MY","product-title":"Your Money","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/your-money?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=business&contentId=MY&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"}]      Please verify you\'re not a robot by clicking the box. Privacy Policy    Larry Turner, who coached Bundy at Owasso High School in Oklahoma, said Bundy had a preternatural calm in difficult situations, although he did not face many of them. He recalled a state semifinal game during Bundy\xe2\x80\x99s junior year in which the opposing team had a runner on second with two outs in a close game. The runner got a good jump as he tried to steal third base. Bundy then hit the batter, forcing the runner to return to second.\xe2\x80\x9cThen he struck the next guy out,\xe2\x80\x9d Turner said in a telephone interview. \xe2\x80\x9cHe came to the bench and said he hit the batter on purpose so the runner would have to go back, and we all believed him.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Turner said Bundy used to stay after practices by himself, flipping tires and pulling heavy chains to build arm strength. And he also had a compassionate side, Turner said.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Owasso High School has often invited Joplin High School, which is about 100 miles away in Missouri, to its annual baseball tournament. In May 2011, after a tornado destroyed Joplin High, Bundy helped organize a relief effort that sent supplies to the city.\xe2\x80\x9cHe was the one who said, \xe2\x80\x98Hey, let\xe2\x80\x99s get this together,\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d Turner said.When Turner met Showalter during spring training this year, he told Showalter he thought Bundy could advance to the major leagues quickly. Showalter seemed a bit hesitant and noncommittal, Turner said.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Then Bundy stormed through the minors, registering 119 strikeouts in 1032/3 innings. And last week, at 2:52 a.m., Turner received a call from Bundy saying he had been called up to the Orioles, called up to a playoff race.Bundy and the Washington Nationals\xe2\x80\x99 Bryce Harper have a chance to become the first teenagers to play in the postseason since Andruw Jones in 1996.\xe2\x80\x9cDylan could have pitched in the big leagues when he was in high school,\xe2\x80\x9d Turner said. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was so far ahead of the game.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on September 26, 2012, on Page B15 of the New York edition with the headline: Teenager Joins Bullpen In Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 Stretch Run.  Order Reprints| Today\'s Paper|Subscribe     Continue reading the main story       We\xe2\x80\x99re interested in your feedback on this page. Tell us what you think.                 ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('Orioles lose to Blue Jays 9-5, split doubleheader - Yahoo', 'View photosBaltimore Orioles\' Adam Jones watches his two-run home run in the fourth inning of the first baseball game of a doubleheader against the Toronto Blue Jays in Baltimore, Monday, Sept. 24, 2012. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky)MoreBALTIMORE (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 The Baltimore Orioles dreaded this doubleheader ever since it became part of their schedule late last month.Beating the same team twice on the same day is not an easy task, even if the opposition is a last-place club in the midst of a losing streak. And so, after Toronto earned a split with a 9-5 win Monday night, the Orioles shrugged their shoulders and looked ahead to another day of chasing the New York Yankees in the AL East."Very hard to sweep a doubleheader in the major leagues," Baltimore manager Buck Showalter said. "It wasn\'t from a lack of effort. That\'s why when you get a rainout, you try to play because you know the challenge ahead of you somewhere down the line. The Blue Jays have a lot of pride."J.P. Arencibia broke open a tight game with a seventh-inning grand slam, leaving the Orioles 1\xc2\xbd games out of first place in the division.In the opener, Adam Jones went 4 for 4 with a homer and two RBIs to lead Baltimore to a 4-1 victory. But the Orioles lost a half-game in the standings to the Yankees, who won 6-3 at Minnesota.The doubleheader came into being after the teams endured a rainout on Aug. 26."You never want to play games like this late in the season," Baltimore right fielder Chris Davis said. "But at the same time, if you can win both of them, you help yourself out. Obviously we weren\'t able to do that."The Orioles fell behind 4-0 in the nightcap and missed several bases-loaded chances to take the lead before Arencibia connected off Jake Arrieta to give Toronto a 9-4 cushion."I think anytime you strand guys on base you know it\'s a missed opportunity," Davis said.Edwin Encarnacion hit his 41st home run for the Blue Jays, who snapped a seven-game skid. Arencibia, who came into the game mired in a 2-for-36 slump, finished with three hits and five RBIs.Toronto long ago fell out of playoff contention, but the Jays were reminded how fun it is while performing before an enthusiastic crowd of 31,015."It\'s pretty impressive the atmosphere they have here," Arencibia said. "It\'s a lot of fun to play in that kind of atmosphere."Ricky Romero (9-14) allowed four runs, eight hits, four walks and a homer in five-plus innings. But a strong performance by the Toronto bullpen enabled the left-hander to end a 13-game losing streak over 15 starts since June 22."Good for him and good for us," Blue Jays manager John Farrell said. "We needed a win and it\'s been a long time since Ricky\'s had a W."Encarnacion put the Blue Jays up 2-0 against Wei-Yin Chen (12-10) with a two-run drive in the first inning. In the second, Arencibia hit a sacrifice fly and Anthony Gose added an RBI single.Robert Andino singled in two runs in the bottom half, but Baltimore left the bases loaded. Nate McLouth hit an opposite-field drive to left in the fifth to get Baltimore to 4-3, but the Orioles again left the bases full.After Moises Sierra homered for Toronto in the sixth, the Orioles loaded the bases with no outs in their half, bringing many in the crowd to their feet. Brad Lincoln replaced Romero and gave up a first-pitch RBI single to J.J. Hardy before striking out Jones. Davis followed with a fly ball to Gose in left field, and Taylor Teagarden was thrown out at the plate after tagging up.Baltimore also loaded the bases with no outs in the ninth, but scored only once on a double-play grounder.In the first game, Orioles rookie Steve Johnson (4-0) allowed three hits over five shutout innings to lower his ERA to 1.62. Half his big league wins have come against Toronto.Although the Blue Jays got two runners on base in three of the first four innings, Johnson worked out of trouble on each occasion.Jim Johnson, the fifth Baltimore pitcher, worked the ninth for his major league-best 48th save in 51 opportunities.Jones\' four hits tied a career high. Now in his seventh season, Jones has already set career highs with 32 homers and 101 runs, and the All-Star center fielder needs only three RBIs to eclipse his previous high of 83, set last year.Jones added a single and a double in the nightcap and has hit safely in 19 of 23 games in September, with six home runs and 13 RBIs."Adam relishes competition," Showalter said. "He\'s obviously had a heck of a year. He\'s turning into quite a player."Henderson Alvarez (9-14) gave up four runs, eight hits and three walks in 5 2-3 innings. He is 2-7 in his last 10 starts.In the fourth, Davis walked and Jones followed with a drive to left to put Baltimore up 2-0. Ryan Flaherty hit a solo shot in the fifth, and Jones singled in the sixth and came home on a double-play grounder.Toronto scored in the eighth on an RBI double by Rajai Davis. With runners on second and third and two outs, Darren O\'Day came in to strike out Kelly Johnson.NOTES: Toronto purchased the contracts of RHPs Shawn Hill and Bobby Korecky and transferred LHP J.A. Happ (foot) to the 60-day DL. ... Orioles LHP Randy Wolf is experiencing discomfort in his left elbow and will undergo an MRI on Tuesday. ... Seventeen of Jones\' HRs have given the Orioles the lead. Baltimore is 23-8 when he homers. ... Toronto\'s first-game defeat was its sixth straight in Baltimore, its longest single-season skid in Charm City since 1980. The Orioles are 10-6 against the Blue Jays, clinching their first season series win over Toronto since 2004. ... Omar Vizquel got two hits to move into a tie with Mel Ott for 40th on the career list with 2,876. ', 'www.yahoo.com'), ('Orioles split twin bill with Toronto - birdswatcher.com', 'People shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t dwell too much on the fact that the Baltimore Orioles dropped the nightcap of last night\xe2\x80\x99s doubleheader to Toronto. More often than not teams split twin bills, and its when you get swept in a doubleheader that you should start to worry. The Orioles won the first game 4-1 as a result of Steve Johnson giving the Orioles five solid innings and putting the team in a position to win. As I said, the best teams have a tough time sweeping a twin bill, and in game two the Orioles seemed just a big sluggish. However the 9-5 score in favor of Toronto isn\xe2\x80\x99t indicative of the game itself, as the Orioles battled on numerous occasions to stay in the game.Courtesy of Joy R. Absalon-US PRESSWIREGame one was in effect a bullpen start, although these days it\xe2\x80\x99s tough to decipher who\xe2\x80\x99s a starter and who\xe2\x80\x99s a reliever. Steve Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s line: 5 IP, 3 H, 0 R, 3 BB, 6 K. Adam Jones hit his 32nd homer of the year, this one of the two-run variety. Ryan Flaherty also chimed in with his fifth home run of the season, as the O\xe2\x80\x99s took the game 4-1. Flaherty\xe2\x80\x99s an interesting case that I\xe2\x80\x99ll probably touch on a bit this off season. He of course was a rule 5 draft choice out of the Chicago Cubs\xe2\x80\x99 organization, and as a result the O\xe2\x80\x99s had to keep him on their big league roster all season or he\xe2\x80\x99d go back to the Cubs (who at various points of the season made it very clear that they\xe2\x80\x99d like to have him back). At this point of course rosters have expanded and Flaherty\xe2\x80\x99s in no risk of being sent down (and thus back to Chicago), however it\xe2\x80\x99s interesting that a rule five draft choice is contributing for a team in the thick of a pennant race.Wei-Yin Chen didn\xe2\x80\x99t bring his best stuff in game two, although he settled down nicely after the first couple of innings. Edwin Encarnacion his a two-run homer in the first inning to put the Orioles down right off the bat, and Toronto added two more in the second to put themselves ahead 4-0. However Robert Andino\xe2\x80\x98s two-RBI single in the second inning put the O\xe2\x80\x99s right back into the game, and Chen was able to regain some composure. The Orioles managed to leave the bases loaded twice over the course of the game, which tells the story right there. However the death blow for the Birds in this game was J.P. Arencibia\xe2\x80\x98s grand slam in the seventh. To that point the Orioles had battled back through a Nate McLouth homer among other things, however that put Toronto in the driver\xe2\x80\x99s seat by a long shot.By virtue of New York beating Minnesota, the Orioles dropped 1.5 games behind in the AL East, however Oakland lost last night at Texas so they didn\xe2\x80\x99t lose any ground in the Wild Card race. The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 magic number to clinch a playoff spot now stands at six games. Again, that means any combination of Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 wins and L.A. Angels\xe2\x80\x99 losses equaling six clinches a playoff spot for the O\xe2\x80\x99s. For the record, L.A. hosts Seattle tonight with Zack Greinke pitching for the Angels and Erasmo Ramirez for Seattle. Orioles fans need to turn into Mariners\xe2\x80\x99 supporters on the side for the next couple of days!The Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 series with Toronto continues tonight, and mercifully it\xe2\x80\x99s only one game! (These doubleheaders throw a lot of people off in a lot of different ways; but come the off season doubleheaders are another thing I might take a look at in terms of pros and cons.) Joe Saunders will get the ball for the O\xe2\x80\x99s, coming off of his best start since being traded to Baltimore. Unfortunately he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have anything to show for it since he didn\xe2\x80\x99t figured into the decision as the game went to the 11th inning. Saunders will be opposed by Toronto\xe2\x80\x99s Aaron Laffey, who\xe2\x80\x99s lost four straight decisions and is battling command issues. All of these games are big from here on out\xe2\x80\xa6the Orioles need to jump on Toronto early tonight to remove any drama from the game early on, and to get the Baltimore faithful singing that Seven Nation Army song for the duration of the game!\xc2\xa0 ', 'birdswatcher.com')]

                    });                 });             }          } })();  BALTIMORE \xe2\x80\x94 At 10 a.m. on a recent Saturday, Aaron Kluttz, 52, wearing a bright orange Brooks Robinson jersey, looked up at the ticket prices posted on the north side of the B&O Warehouse. The warehouse looms above the right-field wall of Oriole Park at Camden Yards.\xe2\x80\x9cI came here because I heard playoff tickets were going on sale today,\xe2\x80\x9d Kluttz said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut my son just told me they\xe2\x80\x99re only available online.\xe2\x80\x9dA lot has changed since September 1997, the last time the Baltimore Orioles were in a pennant race and a fan could be seen realistically looking for playoff tickets outside Camden Yards. Kluttz would have likely had more success then; Major League Baseball had only a fledging presence on the Web, and searching on Google for \xe2\x80\x9cOriole playoff tickets\xe2\x80\x9d wasn\xe2\x80\x99t an option. The search engine\xe2\x80\x99s domain name was registered that month.For many baseball fans in Baltimore, the nuances of following a pennant race have been lost to time and a string of dismal seasons. As the team makes a run at a playoff berth, the city is relearning how to care about and keep up with a pennant contender. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Several hundred yards south of Camden Yards is a place that has served as the city\xe2\x80\x99s recent home for championship chases: the Baltimore Ravens\xe2\x80\x99 M&T Bank Stadium.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The Ravens arrived in Baltimore in 1996. Although they were the transplanted Cleveland Browns, they played like an expansion team, losing football games with regularity several miles away at Memorial Stadium, the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 former home. At Camden Yards, the Orioles were heading to their first of two consecutive American League Championship Series.By September 1998, the Ravens were across the parking lot from the Orioles in their new 68,000-seat stadium. That month the baseball team hit a tailspin, dropping 11 of its final 13 games to finish four games below .500. The Ravens, meanwhile, were beginning an ascent that would lead to a Super Bowl championship in January 2001.Illustrating how this city\xe2\x80\x99s fall focus has almost exclusively been on football, Luther Miracle, an Oriole Park employee, approached Kluttz and held out a photograph.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cYou want to see something nice, take a good look at that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miracle, 88. It was an autographed photo of him with the Ravens\xe2\x80\x99 majority owner, Steve Bisciotti. Miracle, who has been with the Orioles for 51 years, came to know Bisciotti from the owners\xe2\x80\x99 childhood trips to baseball games at Memorial Stadium.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Miracle has seen every pennant race in the Orioles\xe2\x80\x99 history. In 1997 he worked as an usher, but his heart no longer allows that. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t usher anymore, can\xe2\x80\x99t go up and down the stairs,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got leaky valves.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  This autumn he is learning how to slow down and take in a pennant race from a chair, checking the credentials of stadium employees as they go through their routines.Miracle was wearing, at an angle, a \xe2\x80\x9c1983 World Series\xe2\x80\x9d baseball cap, from the last time the Orioles won the championship. The giant gap between good seasons, he said, meant that fans were slow to believe in this year\xe2\x80\x99s team.\xe2\x80\x9cThe way they\xe2\x80\x99ve been playing ball lately, they should\xe2\x80\x99ve been supporting them much more than they did,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cMaybe if we win it, this time next year it\xe2\x80\x99ll be different.\xe2\x80\x9d [{"headline":"Sports","summary":"Get the big sports news, highlights and analysis from Times journalists, delivered to your inbox every week.","product-code":"SP","product-title":"Sports","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/sports?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=SP&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Race\\/Related Newsletter","summary":"Join a deep and provocative exploration of race with New York Times journalists.","product-code":"RR","product-title":"Race Related","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/race-related?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=new&contentId=RR&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"},{"headline":"Your Money","summary":"Every week, get tips on retirement, paying for college, credit cards and the right way to invest.","product-code":"MY","product-title":"Your Money","sample-url":"http:\\/\\/www.nytimes.com\\/newsletters\\/sample\\/your-money?pgtype=subscriptionspage&version=business&contentId=MY&eventName=sample&module=newsletter-sign-up"}]      Please verify you\'re not a robot by clicking the box. Privacy Policy    Pausing, he touched the brim of his cap and added, \xe2\x80\x9cPlus, it\xe2\x80\x99s time for a new damn hat.\xe2\x80\x9dJust inside the baseball stadium, William Jackson, 19, sat on a bench, eyeing his smartphone as he waited to begin taking inventory as part of his job as a retail vendor. A first-year employee of the Orioles, he mostly handles merchandise sales in the upper deck. Jackson\xe2\x80\x99s window into the ebb and flow of a pennant chase is a half-century shorter than Miracle\xe2\x80\x99s, and his context is only from April to September of this year. He has no recollection of the 1997 pennant race.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  His smartphone demonstrated how a modern fan can follow the team without going anywhere. The Orioles, like all major league teams, offer to send text message alerts to their fans\xe2\x80\x99 phones, providing subscribers with updated scores and important highlights. Video streams and computer-simulated pitch-by-pitch accounts are available at a click. It has never been easier to be a fan without attending a game.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  A mile to the northwest at Hollins Market, the city\xe2\x80\x99s public market building built in 1838, business is picking up at Jack\xe2\x80\x99s Poultry & Chuckie\xe2\x80\x99s Fried Chicken. Erik Walder\xe2\x80\x99s family opened the business in 1953, the year before the relocated St. Louis Browns made their debut as the Orioles.Walder, 34, wears an Orioles cap while he greets customers from behind the counter. Lately, regulars have been asking Walder whether he has seen all of the team\xe2\x80\x99s latest feats. \xe2\x80\x9cThey ask me if I stayed up late or if I saw the game last night,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDid I see this play or that play? They\xe2\x80\x99re hanging on every pitch.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  For the crew at Jack\xe2\x80\x99s, 12-hour workdays are frequent, and the long schedule keeps Walder from attending as many games as he would like. In the fall of 1997, he was a 19-year-old freshman at Rider University in New Jersey, with plenty of free time to root on his team in an area dominated by Yankees and Phillies fans.He is now a young father and has to pick his spots. But those are coming more frequently. As the team claws toward the playoffs, he is working the routine of a pennant chase back into his life. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll clean up here after work sometimes and a friend will pick me up and I\xe2\x80\x99ll bring them fried chicken and we\xe2\x80\x99ll go park in the garage across from the stadium and then head in,\xe2\x80\x9d Walder said.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Jack\xe2\x80\x99s is closed on Mondays, and this week Walder was able to take his 3-year-old daughter, Maia, to her first game at Camden Yards for the front end of a doubleheader against the Blue Jays.Some businesses in Baltimore are learning for the first time how to follow a pennant contender. Slainte Irish Pub and Restaurant, which opened in 2004 in the waterfront Fell\xe2\x80\x99s Point neighborhood, dubs itself as the place where \xe2\x80\x9csoccer is religion.\xe2\x80\x9d The bar also reaches out in its advertising to football, hockey and rugby fans, but it has never known a pennant race involving the Orioles.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Surrounding the large flat-screen TV on the first floor bar are scattered soccer pennants hanging from the walls, including one for Spain\xe2\x80\x99s Real Madrid draped just to the side of the screen. But on a clear Monday afternoon, the Orioles were center stage, splitting the doubleheader with the Blue Jays and keeping pressure on the division-leading Yankees. Two Orioles flags fly outside among the collection above Slainte\xe2\x80\x99s red sign.The hostess Loury Davis, who greets guests as they walk up the marble front steps and enter the long, narrow bar, has seen a growing number of black-and-orange faithful crossing the building\xe2\x80\x99s century-old threshold.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve certainly noticed an increase, especially since the All-Star break,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter 14 losing seasons, people here want to celebrate.\xe2\x80\x9d  A version of this article appears in print on September 27, 2012, on Page B15 of the New York edition with the headline: In Ravens\xe2\x80\x99 Territory, Pennant Fever Returns.                     });                 });             }          } })();  MINNEAPOLIS \xe2\x80\x94 With the Yankees embroiled in what at times has felt like a 22-game playoff series against the Baltimore Orioles, Joe Girardi has asked the left-handed reliever Boone Logan to pitch in 14 of those games. That has pushed Logan\xe2\x80\x99s total appearances this season to 77, a career high, and it also qualifies as the most times Girardi has called on a pitcher in his six seasons as a manager.Such is the nature of this extended American League East race, where the Orioles and Yankees have been no further than a game and a half apart in the standings since Sept. 3. Calling on the group of Dave Robertson, Rafael Soriano and especially Logan has mostly worked for Girardi this month, until Tuesday when Logan imploded.After Phil Hughes had pitched effectively over six innings, Logan was called upon to secure the final out of the seventh inning with the bases loaded. But instead he was on the mound when four runs scored as the Minnesota Twins rallied to beat the Yankees, 5-4, at Target Field.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m upset that A, we lost, and B, that I gave up those runs,\xe2\x80\x9d Logan said. \xe2\x80\x9cI had four lefties in a row to get out and I only got one of them out and there\xe2\x80\x99s no excuse. I just didn\xe2\x80\x99t have my stuff tonight.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  The loss was painful for the Yankees, who while they led, 3-1, after six innings, could see in vivid yellow lights on the center field scoreboard that the Toronto Blue Jays had beaten the Orioles, 4-0. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      If the Yankees could have held on they would have cut their magic number to win the division to six. Instead, they were left to ponder how they could have squandered such an opportunity. Photo       Denard Span waving in a run in the seventh as Russell Martin chased after a wild pitch.  Credit             Hannah Foslien/Getty Images           \xe2\x80\x9cWe had an opportunity,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you could look at it the other way, too.\xe2\x80\x9dIn other words, the Yankees did not increase their lead over the Orioles, which remained at a game and a half, but one game was checked off the schedule and the Yankees are still in front with only eight games to play.After the game Girardi and Hughes were repeatedly asked about the decision to take Hughes out in favor of Logan to face Denard Span with the bases loaded in the seventh.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Hughes, like any competitive pitcher, did not want to leave the game, but he also did not want to criticize his manager or his teammate. After the fourth or fifth question on the topic, he simply replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m trying to answer the best way I can.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  He had just struck out Pedro Florimon, the No. 9 hitter, for the second out of the inning, and Span had done nothing against him in his previous three at-bats. But Hughes had shown signs of tiring earlier in the inning, so Girardi did what he had done 76 times previously this season.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Girardi acknowledged that fatigue could be an issue for Logan. But he said he had checked with him before the game and Logan, who did not pitch Monday, said he had been fine. So he made the fateful move.\xe2\x80\x9cIt had been a struggle in that inning,\xe2\x80\x9d Girardi said of Hughes. \xe2\x80\x9cHe had a walk, a 3-2 count, a long at-bat. Boonie had had a ton of success against Span and it didn\xe2\x80\x99t work.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Logan\xe2\x80\x99s outing began inauspiciously. His first offering to Span bounced on the edge of the plate and got behind Russell Martin for a wild pitch, allowing one run to score, cutting the Twins\xe2\x80\x99 deficit to 3-2. Logan still felt he was in command. Photo       Yankees starter Phil Hughes, who was charged with four runs, took the loss.  Credit             Jim Mone/Associated Press           \xe2\x80\x9cO.K., one run,\xe2\x80\x9d Logan said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re still up. I\xe2\x80\x99ve got a lefty in the box, that\xe2\x80\x99s gold. That should be an easy out.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  But Span hit a double into the gap in right-center field and two runs scored as the Twins took the lead, 4-3. Logan walked Ben Revere and Joe Mauer singled to right field, pushing home Span to make the score 5-3.Andruw Jones hit a pinch-hit home run with two outs in the ninth to cut the deficit to a run, but the Twins left-hander Glen Perkins struck out Jayson Nix to end the game. Related Coverage       A Tough Loss for the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 Phil Hughes SEPT. 26, 2012             BATS   Gardner Returns for Pinch-Running Duty SEPT. 25, 2012         BATS   State of the Race: Yankees Facing a Welcome Foe SEPT. 25, 2012                       ', 'www.nytimes.com'), ('Laffey, 5 relievers help Toronto shut out Orioles - yahoo.com', "View photosToronto Blue Jays pitcher Aaron Laffey delivers to a Baltimore Orioles batter during the first inning of a baseball game Tuesday, Sept. 25, 2012, in Baltimore. (AP Photo/Gail Burton)MoreBALTIMORE (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles insist they're not watching the scoreboard. They say they're concentrating on the last-place Toronto Blue Jays.They will need to concentrate harder.On Tuesday night, the Orioles lost for the second straight game, 4-0 to the Blue Jays.Baltimore remained 1 1-2 games behind first-place New York in the AL East. The Yankees lost 5-4 at Minnesota.After Boston's loss, Adam Jones said it was vital to ignore the Yankees.''Trying to get more runs on our scoreboard,'' Jones said.For the first time since Aug. 3, Baltimore was shut out as Aaron Laffey and five relievers combined on a six-hitter.Laffey (4-6) allowed five singles in 5 2-3 innings and won his first game since Aug. 5. He had been winless in his previous six starts. He neither walked nor struck out a batter.''Honestly, he's running on fumes. His stuff is not as sharp and crisp, but you can't take anything away from what he did tonight. He's gone out there on really some guile tonight,'' Toronto manager John Farrell said.Relievers Steve Delabar, Brett Cecil, Brandon Lyon, Darren Oliver and Casey Janssen combined to allow one hit - Chris Davis' seventh-inning double - in 3 1-3 innings.The Orioles loaded the bases in the ninth on an error and two walks, but Ryan Flaherty flied out on the first pitch of his at-bat to end the game.''He's the tying run there,'' manager Buck Showalter said. ''He just missed that ball, hitting it out of the ballpark.''On Monday, Baltimore and Toronto split a doubleheader, with the Blue Jays winning the second game 9-5. The Orioles had just four runners in scoring position.Baltimore leads the season series 10-7 with one game remaining on Wednesday.''You're always going to get everyone's best shot and when we had been struggling and we'd go into certain venues where there's a good emotion in the ballpark, it feeds the other team as well as us,'' Showalter said.The Orioles had won seven of their previous nine.''We got to get some wins. That's what we've been doing since the first day of spring training. Now, we're just in a position where each game matters. It's a cool position to be in,'' Jones said.Joe Saunders (2-3) pitched 6 1-3 innings, allowing four runs - three earned - and 11 hits. He struck out two and walked none.''I didn't feel I had my best stuff, but I feel like I kept my team in the game as best I could. I think we've played like 100 innings the last five days, so bullpen's pretty burnt up, so I had to go as deep as I could,'' Saunders said.The Orioles played an 18-inning game in Seattle a week ago, another 11 innings against the Mariners the next night, and 12 innings in Boston last Saturday.''I think we're fine. I think we might be a little bit tired, but we just have to push through, especially at this time of the year, dig down deep and find whatever you have and compete the best you can. That's about it,'' Saunders said.In the first inning, the Blue Jays took a 1-0 lead on Yan Gomes' RBI single that scored Brett Lawrie, who led off with a single.Rajai Davis beat out an infield single with two outs in the fourth and scored on Adeiny Hechavarria's double.In the seventh, Colby Rasmus and Edwin Encarnacion had consecutive RBI singles to give Toronto a 4-0 lead.''They came up with clutch hits, not really hard hits, but just kind of dinked it in there,'' Saunders said.Dylan Bundy made his second appearance for Baltimore. The 19-year-old pitched a scoreless ninth, but allowed his first hit.NOTES: Orioles LHP Randy Wolf, who's suffering from discomfort in his pitching elbow, will consult with orthopedist Dr. Lewis Yocum before settling on his next step. Yocum performed Tommy John surgery on Wolf's left elbow in 2005. ... Baltimore RHP Jason Hammel, who's been out with a bad right knee, threw about 35 pitches off the mound. He hasn't pitched since leaving a game on Sept. 11. ... Orioles OF Lew Ford is out with a groin injury. ... Bundy and OF L.J. Hoes were given awards for outstanding pitcher and hitter in the Orioles' minor league system. Hoes made his major league debut as a pinch-runner in the ninth. ... Davis was credited with a first-inning single when his batted ball hit Gomes, who was ruled out. ... Baltimore RHP Miguel Gonzalez (7-4, 3.52) faces Toronto RHP Carlos Villanueva (7-6, 3.88) on Wednesday. ", 'www.yahoo.com'), ('Showalter works magic with Orioles', 'Orioles catcher Matt Wieters, left, with Buck Showalter on April 20, says of his manager, \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody\xe2\x80\x99s more comfortable with him.\xe2\x80\x9d(Photo: Gary A. Vasquez, US Presswire)Story HighlightsShowalter turns around team in second full yearOrioles a far from a finished productShowalter has used 50 players and a couple more prospects ready to debutCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMOREBALTIMORE -- Not sure yet why the Baltimore Orioles are more and more likely to be part of this year\'s playoffs?You\'ve seen the stats, maybe sorted them every which way or printed out the numbers. They don\'t add up.Try visiting Camden Yards -- even the long-frustrated folks in Baltimore finally are doing that in increasing numbers.Walk into the Orioles clubhouse, and you\'ll see a camaraderie and a nonchalance that only raises the question -- does that atmosphere breed winning, or does winning breed the confidence?But there still are few concrete clues to how a team that has been outscored this season leads the wild-card race and has been  tied for the American League East lead with the New York Yankees or one game behind New York every day since Labor Day.Out on the field is what seems for all the world like a normal batting practice. Eventually, though, one more Oriole emerges from the tunnel behind home plate.Buck Showalter stops and chats with a coach here, a news reporter there, checks in with a couple of players around the batting cage, eventually wanders around the outfield, striking up a series of conversations, with an ever-present fungo bat at his side.It\'s a daily ritual for the manager, who also carries the only thing resembling a track record that might explain the phenomenon that is his team.Showalter could be excused for requiring "Hi, I\'m " stickers on a team that has used 50 players already and has a couple more prospects on the roster ready to debut any day.But make no mistake, the players know him, his record, his reputation, his expectations."I think Buck\'s been a big change," catcher Matt Wieters said. "Everybody\'s more comfortable with him. It\'s a big thing when you know what your manager is going to expect out of you and you can count on what he\'s going to do for you every day."Compare that with Adam Jones\' comments."It\'s just that his presence, well, you can just feel the change," the center fielder said. "Everybody knows his reputation around here. They know it as someone who\'s going to get on you, and it\'s working for us. He\'s looking at all the small things that are going on."Jones\' comments came nearly two years to the day before Wieters\', not long after Showalter took over a 32-73 team stumbling through the 2010 season."We need an identity as a franchise," said Andy MacPhail, team president at the time. "We need somebody who can put his stamp on this team."Mission accomplished. And if you think the numbers indicate the Orioles\' success is some sort of fluky accident, consider these numbers.This is Showalter\'s second full season as Orioles manager, and entering the week they were on a pace to win 93 games, which would be a 24-game improvement over last year. In 2004, Showalter\'s second full year with the Texas Rangers, they improved by 18 games and he was AL manager of the year.In Showalter\'s second full year with the Arizona Diamondbacks (1999), he led a 35-game improvement. His second full year with the New York Yankees (1993) resulted in a 12-game improvement.Showalter shrugs off the obvious trend, even comes back with, "Yeah, and what\'s the next question?"He knows. The year after he was replaced in both New York and Arizona, those teams won the World Series. Showalter will joke about it \xe2\x80\x94 once even told his Baseball Tonight colleagues at ESPN they could expect an Emmy after he left to return to managing \xe2\x80\x94 but it\'s a sensitive spot.Creating a winner doesn\'t occur overnight, says the ultra-organized manager, even if this year\'s Orioles are something of an overnight sensation. Not if you want to sustain the success."I see a lot of teams that try to cheat the process. You  can\'t  cheat  the  process," he says slowly and with emphasis. "You have to know who you are and know who you\'re not."Putting onus on playersFrom the outside, these Orioles are a team battling to get on the plus side of scoring for the first time since June 26, hardly fitting for one that long ago clinched the franchise\'s first winning record since 1997. And any day now the Orioles might actually have more runs than they\'ve allowed this season \xe2\x80\x94 a recent six-game winning streak  whittled the deficit  to five.Their 16-2 extra-inning record defies explanation \xe2\x80\x94 the 16 wins are an ongoing streak and the longest in baseball since the Cleveland Indians won 17 in 1949.Since July 17, the Orioles are 41-21, including 11 one-run and 11 two-run wins. Overall, they\'re 52-32 in one- and two-run games. They lead the AL with 45 road wins and have won nine of 11 series on the road in the AL East. They\'re 68-0 when leading after seven innings, led by a bullpen that has allowed five earned runs in the 60 extra innings they\'ve played.No wonder the Orioles won\'t go away. Still, how?"We like each other," Showalter said.More important to him is that his players like each other. When he first showed up, players said knowing Showalter was likely to be around for a while had a positive effect on their effort.Showalter, though, described himself to the players as just someone passing through."I understand how shelf life works," he said of the inevitability of a manager getting fired, especially one like himself whose attention to detail and demand for fundamentals are legendary."Most coaches and managers forget how hard this game is. I understand, but I won\'t give in (on demanding the basics)."What he really desires, he said, is peer pressure."One of the things I\'m looking for in my players is whether they care about what their teammates think," Showalter said. "If they care about pleasing their teammates, then it bodes well for us. They don\'t want to let each other down."It wasn\'t always that way. When the Orioles hired him, it was his first experience taking over a team during a season.Late in that 2010 season, he described his frustration:"I have to slow down," he said. "Just because there are a lot of things you want to do. Sometimes I\'ll see something and want to say, \'Stop, can we start spring training right now?\' "Getting most out of rosterMacPhail, whom Showalter lauds for many of the player acquisitions that helped build the current team, left the franchise after last season. Dan Duquette took over as general manager last offseason and has embraced with Showalter the concept of using every bit of their 40-man roster and more.They solidified the successful bullpen. They got through the first half of the season with pretty much a set rotation and haven\'t stopped patching it since, with late-season acquisitions Joe Saunders and Randy Wolf boosting the number of starters used to 12.They have gotten contributions from veteran Jim Thome and resurrected outfielder Lew Ford, who had been out of the majors since 2007. The surprise promotion of teenager Manny Machado increased the buzz in town and created an instant hero. Now, fellow teen phenom Dylan Bundy is with the team, and the right-hander  just might be the next secret weapon.It all goes back to Showalter\'s dictum of knowing who you are."We\'ll talk about a player and say that doesn\'t work for us in Baltimore," he said. "Let\'s don\'t waste a lot of mind power talking about, say, Cecil Fielder coming here. He ain\'t coming here."That was last winter. Dial back your memory a bit further, and there was a time when a packed Camden Yards was a destination for free agents."If we do some good things, we\'ll start attracting people," Showalter said.They\'re attracting fans, who have warmed to the team over the second half and should put the annual attendance over 2 million for the first time since 2007."Our players have gotten a taste of it," Showalter said of the amped-up ballpark atmosphere. "Don\'t think they don\'t notice."Just as Showalter was careful all season to temper the expectations for a team even he wasn\'t certain how long could remain in the race, he knows the Orioles are far from a finished product."Just be glad you\'re relevant" was his message. "I just want to be a part of the Orioles being relevant."But he also recalled what he said was among the best advice he had ever received as a manager: not to fall in love with players he assembled with the expansion Diamondbacks. Few, if any, would be there when the team became successful."Don\'t drink the Kool-Aid," he said, applying the advice to these Orioles. "You\'re looking at some guys who have maybe a little overachieved and things have snowballed."It\'s gotten to the point now, though, that there\'s hardly time left for that snowball to melt."If you get a chance in September, anything can happen," Wieters said. "Coming out of spring training, it was more of a professional feel. It wasn\'t like, \'Oh, my God, what are we doing?\' We\'re still young, but at the same time we have more experience, more maturity."At this point, Showalter says, he\'s more likely to stay out of his players\' way."I\'m not going to  say, \'OK, X number of games left,\' " he said. "You\'ve got to be careful about stating the obvious, things that make them say, \'no (bull).\' "The Orioles\' season needs no explanation at this point. It\'s too late for that."It just verifies the game isn\'t played with a computer," Showalter said. "Hey, ability plays. And sometimes you\'ve got to give it up that money and talent, which is one and the same, can overpower the game."But it\'s also played with effort and heart and guts."CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE ', 'www.usatoday.com')]

[('Yankees\\u2019 Division Lead Shrinks as Ivan Nova\\u2019s Slump ...', '     Supported by    Baseball |                            Blue Jays 6, Yankees 0                                                             Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 Division Lead Shrinks as Nova\xe2\x80\x99s Slump Persists  By DAVID WALDSTEINSEPT. 27, 2012    Continue reading the main story Share This Page  Continue reading the main story                if (             window.magnum             && window.magnum.getFlags().indexOf(\'headlineBalancer\') > 0             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize             && window.magnum.headlineBalancer.shouldRun()         ) {             window.magnum.headlineBalancer.initialize();         }        TORONTO \xe2\x80\x94 Ivan Nova lofted an 87 mile-per-hour slider approximately 18 inches higher than the intended target. It came in chest-high to Edwin Encarnacion, who lashed it into the right-field corner for a two-run double that may have determined Nova\xe2\x80\x99s fate for the rest of the season.In a game the Yankees needed to win to put a safer distance between them and the idle Baltimore Orioles, Nova had another in a series of bad outings, jeopardizing the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 position atop the American League East as well as his standing in the rotation.He gave up four runs and six hits in four and two-thirds innings, and the last-place Toronto Blue Jays went on to win, 6-0. That trimmed the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 lead over the Orioles to one game, while the magic number to clinch the division remained at six, with six games to play.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got to pick it up because we\xe2\x80\x99ve got someone right on our tails,\xe2\x80\x9d Nick Swisher said.Nova is ostensibly scheduled to make one more regular-season start against the Boston Red Sox on Tuesday. But if the Yankees have not sewn up the division by then, they could use someone else for that start \xe2\x80\x94 perhaps David Phelps, the effective rookie who has been pitching out of the bullpen. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      Asked if there might be a change in the rotation, Girardi did not rule it out.\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll see,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI will worry about tomorrow. That\xe2\x80\x99s five days away.\xe2\x80\x9d Photo       Ivan Nova gave up four runs, two of which came on a home run by Brett Lawrie in the third inning, and six hits in four and two-thirds innings.  Credit             Abelimages/Getty Images           Nova said he hoped to make that last start and also made a case for being on the postseason roster. He does not know what is coming next, but he knows that what he has done in his last two starts \xe2\x80\x94 seven earned runs in seven innings \xe2\x80\x94 has not been good.\xe2\x80\x9cEspecially right now in the position we are, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t feel good,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe want to win every day, and we\xe2\x80\x99re not doing that.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Last year Nova was very good, winning 16 games, and he started out this season much the same way, winning 9 of his first 11 decisions. But in the second half of the season he has been unreliable at best, going 2-5 with a 7.05 earned run average, and his slider has been out of whack, as evidenced by the fat one he threw to Encarnacion.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  After spending time on the disabled list with soreness in his right shoulder, Nova came back and had one good start and one bad start before Thursday.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  His troubles against the Blue Jays began in the third inning and multiplied quickly. With one out, he walked Anthony Gose before surrendering a two-run homer to Brett Lawrie, the Jays\xe2\x80\x99 leadoff hitter, who walloped the first pitch he saw, a high fastball, into the Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 bullpen beyond the right-field fence.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  In the fifth, Nova got into serious trouble when the Jays put runners on first and third with only one out and the middle of their order coming up. Nova tried to throw a slider out of the strike zone, but it dangled almost at eye level for Encarnacion, the No. 3 hitter, who drove a bouncing double into the right-field corner. Ichiro Suzuki had trouble picking it up, and both runners scored as the Jays surged ahead, 4-0, providing more frustration for Nova. Photo       Robinson Cano\xe2\x80\x99s base-running error led to a double play on a Nick Swisher flyout. The Yankees lead the Orioles by one game.  Credit             Aaron Vincent Elkaim/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press           \xe2\x80\x9cThis year has been really bad for me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x99m not quitting. I have to get better.\xe2\x80\x9dAs dispiriting as Nova\xe2\x80\x99s performance was, the loss could not be blamed entirely on him. The Yankees\xe2\x80\x99 offense accomplished little against Brandon Morrow, the Blue Jays\xe2\x80\x99 starter, who held them scoreless over seven innings and allowed only four hits. A year ago here, he held the Yankees scoreless over eight innings in his last start against them.\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems like he always figures it out against us,\xe2\x80\x9d Alex Rodriguez said.Morrow induced double-play balls in the fourth and fifth innings to snuff out potential rallies. And with runners on first and second and nobody out in the seventh, Morrow got Curtis Granderson, Russell Martin and Raul Ibanez to make outs. The A\xe2\x80\x99s split four games with the Rangers, leaving Oakland in the same position it was in when the series started \xe2\x80\x94 four games behind the division leader.With six games left in the regular season, the A\xe2\x80\x99s are also locked in a tight race with the Los Angeles Angels and the Baltimore Orioles for the A.L.\xe2\x80\x99s two wild-card spots. Baltimore leads the race, and Oakland is two games ahead of the Angels for the final spot.In the A.L. West, the clock now favors the Rangers, who grabbed a 5-0 lead in the first inning Thursday and survived three home runs by Oakland in the eighth. Still, the A\xe2\x80\x99s tried to find some positive aspects to this series.\xe2\x80\x9cI wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t define it as a bad split,\xe2\x80\x9d said center fielder Josh Reddick, who hit two of Oakland\xe2\x80\x99s five home runs. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s going to be a little more of a grind these last six games. There\xe2\x80\x99s no negative thoughts right now. We know it\xe2\x80\x99s on us. We can\xe2\x80\x99t rely on the Angels or these guys or anybody else to give up ground.\xe2\x80\x9d  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  Oakland starter Travis Blackley lasted only one inning and was followed by five pitchers. Texas was held scoreless the final four innings, but the A\xe2\x80\x99s couldn\xe2\x80\x99t rally past the Rangers. Continue reading the main story        Advertisement  Continue reading the main story      \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s why we\xe2\x80\x99re the best team in the American League right now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ian Kinsler, the Rangers\xe2\x80\x99 second baseman. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope you all don\xe2\x80\x99t forget that. We wanted to respond. We want to be a team that\xe2\x80\x99s tough to put away. Other teams know that we\xe2\x80\x99re very good. They also know our chemistry is very good.\xe2\x80\x9d Photo       Elvis Andrus at second with A\xe2\x80\x99s shortstop Stephen Drew after doubling in the second. He later scored as the Rangers took a 6-1 lead before the A\xe2\x80\x99s rallied with three homers in the eighth.  Credit             Tony Gutierrez/Associated Press           A loss would have cut the Rangers\xe2\x80\x99 division lead to two games heading into this weekend\xe2\x80\x99s series against the Angels. Texas closes the season next week at Oakland. But now, at 92-64, the Rangers own the A.L.\xe2\x80\x99s best record and are in a race with the Yankees to clinch home-field advantage.Kinsler\xe2\x80\x99s leadoff homer and Michael Young\xe2\x80\x99s two-run single in the first inning jolted awake a Rangers offense that had not produced more than three runs in 8 of its last 10 games. Mike Napoli followed with a two-run homer for a 5-0 lead. Starter Matt Harrison pitched six solid innings, allowing four runs and scattering seven hits.  Advertisement  Continue reading the main story  But the A\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x94 the hottest team in the majors since the start of July, with a 51-26 record \xe2\x80\x94 showed how they have vaulted into contention. With Oakland trailing by 9-4 in the eighth inning, Yoenis Cespedes, Brandon Moss and Reddick hit solo home runs off reliever Mike Adams, but the Rangers managed to hang on.
